text: I'm John Harwood with the New York Times
in CNBC the Democratic primary race has
now reached the finish and the only
remaining question is the choreography
of the end game Barack Obama's campaign
is pushing hard to win over enough
uncommitted super-delegates that
combined with those he expects to win in
today's Montana and South Dakota contest
he'll reach the majority needed for
nomination by the time he speaks in
Minnesota tonight from the site of this
summer's Republican National Convention
they've been succeeding at the rate of
more than one every hour now Obama's
aides say they're just 30 delegates
short they expect that rate to increase
sharply once polls close in Montana and
South Dakota still unclear is when
Hillary Clinton might be prepared to
acknowledge his victory exit the race
and begin to unify the party for the
fall campaign parades today denied
reports that she'll concede tonight but
they expect that to happen in the next
few days as one Clinton confidant told
me she'll be a team player it's possible
she might end up literally on Obama's
team as the vice presidential candidate
she signaled her openness to that option
though Obama aides have sought to
discourage that talk in recent weeks
there's little doubt however that
tonight for all intents and purposes
marks the starting line of the
five-month general election campaign
that's why Barack Obama is going to st.
Paul and that's why John McCain has gone
to Louisiana where tonight he will
launch a much more aggressive effort to
distance himself from an unpopular
president bush and begin competing in
earnest with Obama for the support of
swing voters in November
